text: I'm a massive cricket fan, and although that was the first sport I was drawn to for betting it really does seem like a mountain to climb. Do you think, for example, there is enough data (both historical and available in the moment) on pitch conditions? I guess like anything you'd start small and go from there

text: Yes coming at this from a clueless angle. Data scarcity works both ways as more likely to lead to inefficient markets / big advantage for those who can find something useful. It just has some great attributes from what ive seen, large volumes and big enough price movement to inplay events. Furthermore T20 franchise competitions are now everywhere it feels like.

text: That's an interesting point - you're right, it is an intriguing opportunity. It does seem like lots of T20 franchises are here to stay, so over a year you'd have plenty of chances to bet. You'd have some very intense periods and long downtime in-between.

elements.text: That's an interesting point - you're right, it is an intriguing opportunity. It does seem like lots of T20 franchises are here to stay, so over a year you'd have plenty of chances to bet. You'd have some very intense periods and long downtime in-between.

text: I love cricket and use to play it a lot but T20 doesn't hold my interest as a spectacle but I see the appeal of it from trading perspectives. I used to bet a lot on test matches but based on knowledge, not analytics. For me I would not know where to start modelling it properly as it is essentially more about bowler versus batsman matchups and that in itself holds a lot of variation. It is something I would love to get into though but you have to be wary of the match fixing element - you see some terrible examples at times but I suppose no worse than in tennis.

elements.text: I love cricket and use to play it a lot but T20 doesn't hold my interest as a spectacle but I see the appeal of it from trading perspectives. I used to bet a lot on test matches but based on knowledge, not analytics. For me I would not know where to start modelling it properly as it is essentially more about bowler versus batsman matchups and that in itself holds a lot of variation. It is something I would love to get into though but you have to be wary of the match fixing element - you see some terrible examples at times but I suppose no worse than in tennis.

text: As for pitch conditions <@U01LD279D16> that is quite a subjective thing and does it really factor that much in a game that lasts 3 hours? Genuine question as I don't enjoy/watch T20 but in a test match pitch condition is crucial for the first day but you even see some of the former professional players have varying opinions on these things.

text: Yeah for total runs I can see that. Do they even bother that much with T20 in terms of pitch preparation? I mean it seems focused to be a slog fest with the short boundaries so do they ever bother to prepare pitches that turn??

text: There don't seem to be a lot of wrist spinners about in the game at all anymore so pitches need to be receptive to spin for finger spinners to have much impact. In the 90s you had players who could turn the ball on an ice rink but leg spin seems to have died off now.

elements.text: There don't seem to be a lot of wrist spinners about in the game at all anymore so pitches need to be receptive to spin for finger spinners to have much impact. In the 90s you had players who could turn the ball on an ice rink but leg spin seems to have died off now.

text: wrist spinners are extremely important in limited overs cricket even if the pitch doesn't turn much. Very hard to hit them for boundaries.

elements.text: wrist spinners are extremely important in limited overs cricket even if the pitch doesn't turn much. Very hard to hit them for boundaries.

text: What intrigued me was that the game I watched on friday for a short period, the team went into bat at around 2.2, hit two fours off the first 3-4 ball and the price was into 1.8 already.  What I thought were relatively minor events moved the price 3-8%. As i said im clueless but not sure if this is in-line with / similar to tennis.

text: Yes it does seem an overreaction in comparison with it occuring in a 50 overs game or test match. I was watching a 10 overs game on Betfair once and that was even worse. Not seen any 10 overs games since then but in truth I have not looked too hard. It was crazy.

text: The low latency feed betfair are looking to supply is an estimated 3s delay so not quite 'low latency', my understanding is that a lot of the feeds come from guys on the ground via phone (similar to racing with facetime)

text:
<@ULDAVFDRP> i am a cricket person. i trade on cricket (specifically t20s) for a living. i have never traded any other sport but just to let you know t20 markets are very tough to crack (compared to test matches and ODIs anyway) but it can be worth your time.
as for models you can scrape data online and create a base model (which doesn't include pitch information but this is unlikely to do well). pitch conditions - even in the shortest format have a huge impact on the outcome. i have been gathering pitch data by hand over the last 5 years so i have enough data to model the pitch conditions. but i dont think you can easily obtain this info anywhere.
my 2 cents - its probably worth it but it will require a lot of work. test matches are significantly easier than t20s. happy to chat more about this if youd like

elements.text:
i am a cricket person. i trade on cricket (specifically t20s) for a living. i have never traded any other sport but just to let you know t20 markets are very tough to crack (compared to test matches and ODIs anyway) but it can be worth your time.
as for models you can scrape data online and create a base model (which doesn't include pitch information but this is unlikely to do well). pitch conditions - even in the shortest format have a huge impact on the outcome. i have been gathering pitch data by hand over the last 5 years so i have enough data to model the pitch conditions. but i dont think you can easily obtain this info anywhere.
my 2 cents - its probably worth it but it will require a lot of work. test matches are significantly easier than t20s. happy to chat more about this if youd like

text: I started off trading cricket but soon realised how many hours I would need to become proficient. It's tempting on the surface because of the volumes and the price movements, but they are brutal when you're on the wrong side. Which happened to be more often than I expected
